p: Switching to non-intravenous injection sites. Using data from accidental needle-stick injuries, the risk of HIV transmission following intramuscular poke is about 3 times less compared to intravenous poke (0.002 vs. 0.006) [ 30, 31]. We assume from ethnographic observations that on average about 25% of BTH injections are intramuscular or subcutaneous [ 32]. Rich et al. [ 17] suggest that the probability of HIV transmission through subcutaneous injection is negligible.
